game

Class JTetris

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • javax.swing.JComponent
          • game.JTetris
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable

    public class JTetris
extends javax.swing.JComponent
    This is a tetris game in a window. It handles the GUI and the animation. The Piece and Board classes handle the lower-level computations.
    Author:
    Nick Parlante
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Method Detail

      • startGame

        public void startGame()
        Sets the internal state and starts the timer so the game is happening.

      • enableButtons

        public void enableButtons()
        Sets the enabling of the start/stop buttons based on the gameOn state.

      • stopGame

        public void stopGame()
        Stops the game.

      • setCurrentPiece

        public int setCurrentPiece(Piece piece,
                           int x,
                           int y)
        Given a piece, tries to install that piece into the board and set it to be the current piece. Does the necessary repaints. If the placement is not possible, then the placement is undone, and the board is not changed. The board should be in the committed state when this is called. Returns the same error code as Board.place().

      • pickNextPiece

        public Piece pickNextPiece()
        Selects the next piece to use using the random generator set in startGame().

      • addNewPiece

        public void addNewPiece()
        Tries to add a new random piece at the top of the board. Ends the game if it's not possible.

      • computeNewPosition

        public void computeNewPosition(Controls verb)
        Figures a new position for the current piece based on the given verb (LEFT, RIGHT, ...). The board should be in the committed state -- i.e. the piece should not be in the board at the moment. This is necessary so dropHeight() may be called without the piece "hitting itself" on the way down.

        Sets the ivars newX, newY, and newPiece to hold what it thinks the new piece position should be. (Storing an intermediate result like that in ivars is a little tacky.)

      • tick

        public void tick(Controls verb)
        Called to change the position of the current piece. Each key press call this once with the verbs LEFT RIGHT ROTATE DROP for the user moves, and the timer calls it with the verb DOWN to move the piece down one square.

        Before this is called, the piece is at some location in the board. This advances the piece to be at its next location.

        Overriden by the brain when it plays.

      • repaintPiece

        public void repaintPiece(Piece piece,
                         int x,
                         int y)
        Given a piece and a position for the piece, generates a repaint for the rectangle that just encloses the piece.

      • paintComponent

        public void paintComponent(java.awt.Graphics g)
        Draws the current board with a 1 pixel border around the whole thing. Uses the pixel helpers above to map board coords to pixel coords. Draws rows that are filled all the way across in green.
        Overrides:
        paintComponent in class javax.swing.JComponent

      • updateTimer

        public void updateTimer()
        Updates the timer to reflect the current setting of the speed slider.

      • createControlPanel

        public java.awt.Container createControlPanel()
        Creates the panel of UI controls.
